From One Grad To Another Scholarship
This scholarship was established to ease the financial strain for future nursing students in the RN program who are attempting to juggle the requirements of school and the responsibilities of parenthood. Applicant must be either a single or married parent, who struggle under the burden of economic hardship. Preference given to those individuals who have worked in a health related field before entering the nursing program. Students are selected not by grade point average, but who show promise in their clinical work. Donor/Thank You Letter: Ann Aswegan more...

Gary Coll Journalism Fellowship
Annual fellowship for sophomores, juniors or seniors attending the University of Wisconsin-Oshkosh who are majoring in Journalism. Selection based on participation in Journalism activities outside of UW area. Due date and number of awards may vary. Nonrenewable. more...

Gary Coll Journalism Fellowship
This award was established in honor of Gary Coll, professor of journalism at UW Oshkosh for 36 years. The fellowship provides financial assistance to journalism students for professional opportunities. Funding may be used to partially cover travel and related expenses for the following opportunities: 1) an internship or job shadow at a prominent journalism organization in a distant city; 2) a journalism conference; or 3) an academic competition for journalism students. Applicant must be a full-time undergraduate enrolled the Oshkosh campus. Applicant must be majoring in journalism, must have completed at least 60 credits, and must have a minimum 2.5 cumulative GPA. GPA is one of the key selection criteria. This award will be paid in the semester in which the recipient is participating in the opportunity. more...

arts”, such as, but not limited to, literature, drama, music, philosophy or language;

(4) Financial need must be a prime consideration, i.e., it is the donor’s intent to help
alleviate a student’s need to maintain a heavy employment schedule;
(5) At least one award should be made annually; more...

Genevieve Carnes Memorial Scholarship Fund (Sah)
sophomore, junior or senior to be enrolled full time majoring in exercise & sport science
good academic standing more...

Genevieve Durand Siers Memorial Scholarship
Genevieve Durand was born the youngest of four children in Chicago, Illinois, on December 28, 1920. After graduating from Immaculata High School, she started her nursing studies at St. Anne’s Hospital Nursing School in Chicago, including floor work at the hospital. During WWII, she served in the Cadet Nurse Corps for several months in 1944.
We believe that Gen was the first in her family to pursue higher education. Unfortunately, before she was able to complete her studies she withdrew from the program so she could care for her mother and then her father at the end of their lives.
Gen worked and volunteered for a variety of organizations, including the Catholic Guild for the Blind. She married Ambrose Siers in 1964, and in 1965 gave birth to her first and only child, Judith. Once she became a mother, she stayed home to raise her daughter. Sadly, she was diagnosed with lung cancer in fall of 1981 and passed away on March 5, 1982, at the age of 61.
We are establishing this memorial scholarship on the centenary of her birth in order to support nursing students at Madison College. Preference will be given to first generation college students and to students of color. more...

Geology Scholarship
Scholarship for incoming freshmen enrolling at the University of Wisconsin-Oshkosh who will be majoring in Geology or Earth Science. Applicants must have graduated in the top 25% of class. Nonrenewable. more...

Applicants must have attended the high school for at least four semesters and have financial need. Preference given to Physical Education majors. Nonrenewable. more...

George Gilkey Special Collections Research Scholarship Fund (General, Graduate)
Recipient must be enrolled full time at UW-La Crosse;
Recipient must be in good academic standing;
Recipient may be a freshman, sophomore, junior, senior or graduate student;
At least one award should be made annually;
Applicants must submit an intellectual product produced using materials preserved in the Murphy Library Special Collections unit. Entries must be single-authored, and they may be a paper or project which the applicant has written or has prepared for a class but has not been published. Only one submission per applicant will be accepted. Intellectual works will be judged on the use of the Murphy Special Collections, development and argumentation of the ideas presented, originality of the research, quality of writing and documentation, and overall or potential contribution to academic scholarship. Murphy Library will retain a copy of the winning intellectual work. more...

High school graduate of Milwaukee Public Schools, demonstrated academic achievement, financial need, set to enroll as a full-time student to pursue a degree at the School of Architecture and Urban Planning. Criteria may also include: review of performance on tests measuring ability and aptitude for college work; recommendations from instructors, advisors, or employers; applicant’s evidence of a good moral character and written statements provided by the applicant. This award is renewable based on continued enrollment and good academic standing in the School of Architecture and Urban Planning for up to four years. more...

Gertrude And Donald "Sandy" Gordon Jazz Scholarship Fund (Sac)
freshman, sophomore, junior or senior to be enrolled full time with an interest in jazz music
music students or pursuing an undergraduate degree in music
at least a 2.5 gpa
if eligible, may receive a maximum of four years
Performance Guidelines
Piano: Two pieces required (at least one memorized): 1) An allegro sonata movement from
Beethoven, Mozart or Haydn OR Prelude and Fugue by J.S. Bach, 2) Any piece composed in the
Romantic or Contemporary Era. Any repertoire substitutions should be addressed PRIOR to the
audition date.
Strings: a 5-10 minute performance of two contrasting styles or movements of Class A-level
solo literature or above. Memorization is optional. Accompaniment is not required, but is
encouraged.*
Winds: a 5-10 minute performance of two contrasting styles or movements of Class A-level
solo literature or above. Memorization is optional. Accompaniment is not required, but is
encouraged.*
Percussion: a 5-10 minute performance of Class A-level solo literature or above on snare drum
OR timpani, AND a keyboard percussion instrument. Memorization is optional.
Accompaniment is not required, but is encouraged.*
Voice: a 5-10 minute performance of contest-quality solo literature. If the length of one piece is
less than five minutes, a second piece of contrasting tempo, style or language is preferred.
Memorization is optional, but suggested. Vocalists must provide their own accompanist.*
All auditionees will be expected to demonstrate sight-reading abilities
A list of local accompanists is available upon request from the Department of Music.
All auditionees must make their own arrangements with their accompanist of choice.
Questions may be referred to: Dr. Christopher Frye, Department of Music Scholarship
Committee, phone: (608) 785 – 6729 or e-mail: frye.chri@uwlax.edu more...

Awards given in spring are for the following school year. E.G. applications reviewed in Spring 2022 are for Fall 2022. more...

Gloria Gudmundson Associate Degree Nursing Scholarship
The Gloria Gudmundson Associate Degree Nursing Scholarship fund was established by Gloria Gudmundson, a former member of the ADN faculty and her husband, Wayne Musser, Jr. Throughout years of teaching nursing students in the program, Gloria gained an awareness and appreciation of the financial challenges experienced by many students as they managed their educational pursuits, as well as personal, family, and employment responsibilities. This scholarship is meant to provide financial assistance to be utilized for tuition and/or related educational equipment for qualifying ADN students. Gloria and Wayne also recognize the increasing need for an expanding number of quality professional nurses to meet projected needs within the health care system of the future more...

Applicant must be admitted as an incoming freshman or transfer student for Summer 2022 or Fall 2022 or must be enrolled full-time as an undergraduate student at the Oshkosh campus. Applicant must have a declared art major with a studio emphasis. Applicant must have financial need based on the FAFSA. Recipient must be enrolled full-time to receive the award. Grant Langer Memorial Scholarship
This scholarship was established to honor Grant Langer and his service to the community as a firefighter. The purpose is to provide a scholarship to someone who is studying to be a firefighter. See scholarship addendum for criteria. From Grant’s earliest days he always wanted to become a
firefighter. He went to work for Mt Horeb Fire, Fitchburg Fire, and Fitch-Rona EMS while obtaining his degree in 2016, from the Madison College Fire Academy. In 2017 he went to work for the Memphis Fire Department as a firefighter/paramedic. Grant had an infectious personality and performed
every job in the fire service with enthusiasm and skill. Although he was young when he died, he showed everyone who met him what it takes to succeed in the fire service. Thank you: Michael and Barbara Teff more...

Applicant must have a minimum 3.0 cumulative GPA and must possess outstanding qualities of character, scholastic ability, and leadership. This award will be paid out in Fall 2021. more...

You must be majoring food service or restaurant management to be eligible for this award. Preference is given to students who are employed by members of the Wisconsin Restaurant Association having their businesses in the greater Milwaukee area. more...

You must be seeking a degree or certification in one of the following fields: fire science, police science, law enforcement, EMT, or a related field. Intended for a non-traditional resident of Wisconsin from Milwaukee county who is returning to school after a gap in their education. Must be a junior, senior or Master’s candidate enrolled in at least six credits, with a minimum 2.0 cumulative GPA and demonstrated financial need. Not intended for PhD candidates. more...

Greater Milwaukee Foundation Journal Foundation/Donald And Barbara Abert Scholarship
The Greater Milwaukee Foundation Journal Foundation/Donald and Barbara Abert Scholarship is funded by a generous gift from the Greater Milwaukee Foundation. Eligibility for this academic merit scholarship includes:
Major in Journalism, Advertising and Media Studies in the journalism or media studies track (ad/pr track not eligible)
Demonstrated financial need as shown on the FAFSA

Full-time enrollment
U.S. citizen
Preference will be given to students with an affiliation with the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel, the Milwaukee operations of E.W. Scripps Co. (for example, WTMJ-TV) or Gannett Wisconsin (for example, the Green Bay Press Gazette). Contact the department for a full list of affiliated companies. An affiliation could include a job at one of these companies or a relative who works or worked at one of these companies.
Students who have an up-to-date Panther Scholarship Portal General Application and the College of Letters & Science Scholarships and Awards Application will be considered, typically in spring each year between February and April. No additional or separate application is required; students should thoroughly fill out the Panther Scholarship Portal General Application and the College of Letters & Science Scholarships and Awards Application. Awards given in spring are for the following school year so students graduating that same spring or summer are not eligible. E.G. applications reviewed in Spring 2022 are for Fall 2022; students graduating in May or August 2022 are not eligible. more...

Greater Milwaukee Foundation Mary Jo Read Fellowship For Graduate Students
The Mary Jo Read Geography Fund, with estimated assets of more than $1 million, will benefit students in the Department of Geography by providing scholarships, fellowships, and merit awards to students who demonstrate academic excellence in the field. Fellowships for Geography graduate students typically provide additional financial support to those also holding teaching, project, or research assistantships. Selection is based on the student’s academic and research record.
Students will be considered typically in spring each year between April and June. No additional or separate application is required. Awards given in spring are for the following school year so students graduating that same spring or summer are not eligible. E.G. applications reviewed in Spring 2022 are for Fall 2022; students graduating in May or August 2022 are not eligible. more...

Coursework should demonstrate a well-rounded liberal arts background. Consideration may be given to returning students. more...

Heidi Gustafson Eldred Study Abroad Scholarship
• Recipient must be enrolled full-time at UW-L
• Recipient must be a graduate of Beloit Memorial High School
• Recipient can be a freshman, sophomore, junior, or senior participating in a study abroad program through the UWL Office of International Education and Engagement. Preference to students who are in a semester-long study abroad program.
• Recipient must be in good academic standing with a minimum GPA of 2.0
• Financial need must be considered.
• Statement of financial need must be included. Preference for students that are responsible for at least 50% of their education costs. This must be addressed in the financial need statement on the general application.
• Amount awarded up to $5000 varies based on student’s financial need and the length of the program. Donor prefers to support semester-long study abroad programs.
., Upon completion of the study abroad program the student recipient will initiate a meeting with the donor to discuss their study abroad experience. more...

Helen A. Berry Memorial Scholarship
The Helen A. Berry Memorial Scholarship is given to a student accepted into The Washington Center internship program for an experiential learning internship in Washington DC. The Washington Center program includes:
A full-time internship at a site in the Washington DC area which could be at a government agency, a nonprofit, or a corporate entity
One class run by The Washington Center chosen from a wide list of options
Workshops, advising, and networking events focused on professional and career development
The benefits of this program include:
Enhance your resume with hands-on experience
Obtain valuable career and job skills
Network with industry professionals and students from around the country
Explore different career paths and opportunities
Earn 12 UWM credits – students will work with their UWM advisor to select appropriate internship and independent study credit and possibly an online UWM class
To learn more about The Washington Center’s program, see https://twc.edu/programs/academic-internship-program
This scholarship will cover significant portions of the costs of The Washington Center program and in-state UWM tuition for up to 12 credits so that the student continues to make progress towards graduation while spending a semester away from UWM.
To be considered for this scholarship, students must have demonstrated financial need as shown on the FAFSA, be a junior or senior during the time of the internship, and have a cumulative GPA of 3.25 or higher.
Applications are typically accepted in Spring semester for summer or fall internships, but students interested in completing the internship in a spring semester can inquire at let-sci@uwm.edu between October 1 and November 30 to see if scholarships are available. more...

Hiebing Endowed Scholarship

We love what careers in the marketing, creative, digital and advertising fields have meant to us and want for a more diverse group of professionals to benefit from it. We need more diversity in these careers and hope that this will help open more up more avenues into this field and create opportunities for talented and passionate students of color. more...

High School Business Model Competition Scholarship
Students who place first, second, or third in the UW Oshkosh High School Business Model Competition are eligible to receive a scholarship to UW Oshkosh. Available award funding may vary from year to year, but will follow the model below:
1st place: $8,000 scholarship
2nd place: $5,000 scholarship
3rd place: $2,000 scholarship
Total available scholarship amount will be divided evenly among all team members, regardless of whether or not each team member qualifies to receive their portion of the scholarship. The award will be paid out over two years. Recipients must enroll at UW Oshkosh for their first year of college, immediately following their senior year of high school. Recipients must maintain full-time enrollment at any of the UW Oshkosh campuses in order to receive the award and must maintain good standing in order to qualify for the second year of the award.
Students who do not attend UW Oshkosh will receive a cash prize of no more than $200. more...

Applications are typically accepted in spring each year between February and April. Students must also apply for study abroad approval through the UWM Center for International Education. Their deadline to apply for study abroad is typically March 1. more...

Honors College Capp Scholarship
This scholarship is awarded to high school Cooperative Academic Partnership Program (CAPP) students who have been admitted to the UW Oshkosh Honors College as incoming freshmen for Summer 2022 or Fall 2022. Applicant must apply during their senior year in high school. Applicant must have either successfully completed at least one CAPP course or be currently enrolled in a CAPP course at the time of application. Recipient must be enrolled full-time in Fall 2022 in order to receive the award. This scholarship is not renewable. Students may apply for the CAPP Scholarship and the Honors College CAPP Scholarship, but are only eligible to receive one of the awards. Students enrolled at the Fox Cities or Fond du Lac campuses are eligible to apply for this award if they plan to enroll in the Honors College. However, honors courses are currently only offered at the Oshkosh campus. more...

Inez And Louis Chicquette Scholarship
This scholarship was established in honor of Inez and Louis Chicquette, lifelong supporters of public education in the state of Wisconsin. Applicant must be a full-time undergraduate enrolled in the special and early childhood education program at the Oshkosh campus. Applicant must have met Gateway I requirements and been admitted, or have applied for fall admission, to the Teacher Education Program. Applicant must demonstrate academic achievement and must be in good standing with the department of special and early childhood education. Preference will be given to applicants with a major in special education. Special consideration will be given to an applicant who has served in the military or has had a family member serve within the last 10 years. Financial need based on an essay may be considered, but will not be the deciding factor in selection. This award will be paid out in Fall 2021. more...

Applicant must have completed IS 201 or CS 221 with a B or better and must be enrolled in or have completed IS 318 or IS 445. Students will automatically be considered for this award based on the Business Scholars Program and Scholarship Application. Intoxalock $3,000 Drunk Driving Prevention Scholarship
At Intoxalock, our overall mission is to ensure safer roads for all by preventing drunk driving. Whether our ignition interlock devices are being used to fulfill a mandatory legal requirement or as an additional measure to help prevent drunk driving, the main goal is the same. Ignition interlock devices help separate drinking from driving and are effective at cutting down the number of alcohol-related traffic injuries and fatalities.
In an effort to expand our message of drunk driving prevention, we are happy to offer our $3,000 Drunk Driving Prevention Scholarship to an individual who is currently attending, or has been accepted for enrollment, at any accredited two or four year U.S. college or university. Students interested in all fields of study are encouraged to apply! more...

J. David Hoeveler Merit Scholarship
This scholarship is given to a declared History major who has taken at least 12 credits in History and with demonstrated academic excellence. Qualified applications will have a minimum cumulative GPA of 3.25, junior standing and will be enrolled full-time. Scholarships may be renewable for one additional year if the student still meets the criteria, and scholarships will be valued at $5,000 per year.
This scholarship is funded through a generous gift from history professor J. David Hoeveler.
Students who have an up-to-date Panther Scholarship Portal General Application and the College of Letters & Science Scholarships and Awards Application will be considered, typically in spring each year between February and April. No additional or separate application is required; students should thoroughly fill out the Panther Scholarship Portal General Application and the College of Letters & Science Scholarships and Awards Application. Awards given in spring are for the following school year so students graduating that same spring or summer are not eligible. E.G. applications reviewed in Spring 2022 are for Fall 2022; students graduating in May or August 2022 are not eligible. more...

J. H. Findorff & Son Construction Industry Continuing Student Scholarship
J.H. Findorff & Son, Inc. is one of Wisconsin’s leading builders. With offices in Madison and Milwaukee, Findorff currently employs an average of 600 construction professionals and trades people, and completes over $300 million in construction annually. For more than 120 years, Findorff employees have demonstrated leadership, integrity, and innovation on thousands of projects throughout Southern Wisconsin. Findorff also prides itself on remaining at the forefront of cutting edge construction processes, equipment and technology. Findorff continues to develop superior resources for its clients and continues to expand upon their expertise in areas such as: Building Information Modeling, Integrated Project Delivery, Jobsite Safety, Quality and Sustainable Building Practices. This scholarship is available to continuing students enrolled in construction-related programs with a 3.0 GPA or higher. Donors/Thank You Letter: Dave Beck-Engel more...

J. H. Findorff & Son Construction Industry New Student Scholarship
J.H. Findorff & Son, Inc. is one of Wisconsin’s leading builders. With offices in Madison and Milwaukee, Findorff currently employs an average of 600 construction professionals and trades people, and completes over $300 million in construction annually. For more than 120 years, Findorff employees have demonstrated leadership, integrity, and innovation on thousands of projects throughout Southern Wisconsin. Findorff also prides itself on remaining at the forefront of cutting edge construction processes, equipment and technology. Findorff continues to develop superior resources for its clients and continues to expand upon their expertise in areas such as: Building Information Modeling, Integrated Project Delivery, Jobsite Safety, Quality and Sustainable Building Practices. This scholarship is available to new students who are pursuing construction industry-related careers. Donors/Thank You Letter: Dave Beck-Engel more...

Jake & Janet Hoeschler Award For Excellence
The Jake and Janet Hoeschler Award for Excellence recognizes a CBA student who will graduate in either December or May of the current academic year. The Hoeschler Family wishes to recognize students who not only have a solid academic record, but who have also demonstrated a creative approach to identifying, planning, and executing one or more projects. The award is for academic accomplishment and leadership on campus and in the community.
graduating senior during or at the end of the academic year majoring in the College of Business Administration
based upon academic excellence and qualities of leadership demonstrated in campus and community activities
must provide three names of individuals who will submit letters of reference on your behalf more...

based on academic excellence and not financial need for the purpose of recruiting and/or retaining superior students
commitment, interest and involvement in campus and community activities, including such things as, but not limited to, internship experience more...

James & Dorathea Levenson Ecology And Field Biology Fellowship
The James & Dorathea Levenson Ecology and Field Biology Fellowship is given to graduate students conducting field work at the UWM Field Station or Cedarburg Bog, typically for work done during the summer term. Preference will be given to students who are military veterans. Applications are typically accepted between February and April. more...

James Brett Lawrence Memorial Music Scholarship
This scholarship was created in memory of James Brett Lawrence. James was born in 1966 and he died in 1988, at the age of 22. He attended Madison College and was an enthusiastic participant in the music program. Applicant must intend to attend Madison College and participate in a music performance ensemble. For new Madison College students.

James H. Fischer Family Scholarship
This scholarship was established in 2013 by James H. Fischer ’70 to encourage high school graduates to continue their education. This scholarship is awarded to a graduating senior who is admitted to the Oshkosh campus for Summer 2022 or Fall 2022. Applicant must plan to major in biology, biomedical science, environmental health, medical imaging, microbiology, PP-medicine, or geology. Applicant must have a minimum 3.0 high school GPA and must not have more than one sibling. Financial need is not a consideration. Recipient must enroll full-time in Fall 2022 in order to receive the award. This award shall be renewed one time, provided the recipient continues to meet the criteria of the award and funding is available. more...

James H. Mack Scholarship For Public Policy Advocacy (Cls)
recipient must be enrolled full time at UW-La Crosse with a major in political science, public administration or economics
recipient must be a junior or a senior
recipient must show interest in pursuing a career in the public policy arena in either the public or private sector
recipient must have reputation for integrity and good ethical behavior
recipient must have participated in the political process (e.g. public office, assisting others in attending public office, student government and/or campus association relevant to this award)
with the application, recipient must submit an essay on a domestic public policy issue (of the recipient’s choice) demonstrating knowledge of the issue and promoting arguments in support as well as opposition to the issue in addition to stating personal point of view on the issue and why
General Category more...

Applicant must be a full-time undergraduate enrolled at the Oshkosh campus. Applicant must be admitted, or have applied for spring admission, to the College of Business. Preference will be given to applicants with an emphasis in entrepreneurship and small business management. Applicant must have a demonstrated interest in entrepreneurship as demonstrated through extra-curricular activities and entrepreneurial pursuits. This award will be paid out in Fall 2022. more...

James T. Schremp Memorial Scholarship Fund

James W. Unger Scholarship
This scholarship was established in memory of James W. Unger, professor of biology at UW Oshkosh for 30 years. Applicant must be a full-time undergraduate student enrolled at the Oshkosh campus. Applicant must have a declared biology, biomedical science, or microbiology major, a minimum of 36 credits completed, and a minimum 3.0 cumulative GPA. Financial need based on an essay will be considered, but will not be the determining factor. Previous recipients are eligible to apply, but students may only receive the award twice. This award will be paid out in Fall 2022. more...

Jan And Tom Montiegel Scholarship
The Jan and Tom Montiegel Scholarship is an academic merit scholarship given to students with demonstrated academic excellence who are enrolled full-time in a major within the College of Letters & Science.
New freshmen who have not started at UWM will apply as part of the freshman scholarship application process between October and January of their senior year of high school. Applications are reviewed in January and February, and recipients are notified in February or March. Students who receive it as a freshmen will receive the scholarship for four years total.
Current UWM students who have an up-to-date Panther Scholarship Portal General Application and the College of Letters & Science Scholarships and Awards Application will be considered, typically in spring each year between February and April. No additional or separate application is required; students should thoroughly fill out the Panther Scholarship Portal General Application and the College of Letters & Science Scholarships and Awards Application. Awards given in spring are for the following school year so students graduating that same spring or summer are not eligible. E.G. applications reviewed in Spring 2022 are for Fall 2022; students graduating in May or August 2022 are not eligible. more...

Jan Jefferson Memorial Scholarship
This scholarship was established to honor Jan Jefferson and her service to the. community as a firefighter. The purpose is to provide c scholarship to someone who is studying to be a firefighter. See scholarship addendum for criteria. In 1980 Jan was selected by the Madison Fire Department to be in the first class that included women. In fact, Jan was one of the first women to be hired by any fire department. As a member of the MFD Jan became a paramedic and eventually retired as a Lieutenant after 25 years. She did her job with class and paved the way for future women to be hired. Women on the Madison Fire Department as well as nationwide owe a debt of gratitude to Jan Jefferson for how she handled herself as one of the first female firefighters in the country. Thank you: Michael and Barbara Teff more...

Thank You: Jane Villa more...

For new incoming freshmen admitted by February 1st who are graduates of MPS; Resident of the City of Milwaukee; have demonstrated financial need (filed a FAFSA); Priority preference for music or music education degree program; if none, 2nd preference for education degree leading to teaching career; if none, 3rd preference for nursing degree; no double majors outside of 3 above areas. Non-renewable. more...

Students must have a minimum 2.5 GPA and financial need. Applicants must participate in summer internships at Milsco Manufacturing, Redgranite, Wisconsin or Osborn International, North American, Richmond, Indiana. An interview is required. Jean Erdman And Thomas J. King Scholarship
This scholarship was established by Dr. Jean Erdman ’72, professor in the College of Education and Human Services, and her husband, Thomas J. King. Applicant must be a full-time undergraduate or an enrolled graduate student (full-time enrollment is not required) within the College of Education and Human Services at the Oshkosh campus. Undergraduate applicants must have been admitted, or have applied for fall admission, to the Teacher Education Program and must be pursuing a regular education licensure in grades 4K-12 (special education licensures are not eligible). Graduate applicants must be admitted to the MSE Teaching and Learning program. Applicant must show promise in a teaching career and must show financial need (either based on the FAFSA or a letter from a COEHS faculty member). This award will be paid out in Fall 2022. more...

The 2002 Practical Nursing class had the honor of being Mrs. Nelson-Milleson’s last class. With all her hard work and dedication she made the practical nursing program at the Fort Atkinson campus what it is today. They honor her with this scholarship. Available for full-time Practical Nursing students with a 3.0 GPA or higher.

Jeanne Bissell Endowed Scholarship Fund

This woman should be motivated and ready to apply themselves to their coursework. Special consideration should be given to those from under-served communities and women of color. more...

Jeffrey K. Kunkel Scholarship
The Kunkel Scholarship provides $1,000 to one UWM student in the College of Letters & Science or in the School of Freshwater Sciences. The award alternates between the two units each year and is chosen based on overall academic merit and financial need. Eligible students must also be enrolled full-time.
Students who have an up-to-date Panther Scholarship Portal General Application and the College of Letters & Science Scholarships and Awards Application will be considered, typically in spring each year between February and April. No additional or separate application is required; students should thoroughly fill out the Panther Scholarship Portal General Application and the College of Letters & Science Scholarships and Awards Application. Awards given in spring are for the following school year so students graduating that same spring or summer are not eligible. E.G. applications reviewed in Spring 2022 are for Fall 2022; students graduating in May or August 2022 are not eligible. more...

Jeffrey Kranz Management Scholarship
The Jeffrey Kranz Scholarship is available to a senior or second semester junior majoring in Management at the University of Wisconsin, Whitewater. You must have a minimum GPA of 3.5 to be eligible for this award. more...

Jerry Lane Memorial Scholarship
This fund was created upon the death of Jerry Lane. Jerry dedicated his life to the baking industry, not only creating, but also sharing his knowledge of the baking industry to the many apprentices that worked at Lane’s Bakery over his 50 years of baking. Therefore, the scholarship is to be used to assist students to become Bakers. more...

John A. Johnson Foundation Scholarship
The John A. Johnson Scholarship Fund was created by the John A. Johnson Foundation. George H. Johnson established the Foundation while he served as President of the former Gisholt Machine Company, A company which manufactured tools. Gisholt Machine Company made substantial contributions to the John A. Johnson Foundation, which permitted the creation of an endowment fund that for 50 years provided scholarships to Madison area students and supported numerous local public charities. Donor/Thank You Letter: The Madison Community Foundation
Criteria:
 Be a qualified, full-time Madison College student
 Demonstrate financial need
 Maintain a minimum grade point average of 2.5 to 4.0 grading system. more...

John And Linda Schuh History Scholarship
This scholarship was established by Dr. John Schuh, ’69 and his wife, Linda. The award is given to a full-time undergraduate majoring in history within the College of Letters and Science at the Oshkosh campus. Recipient must achieve senior standing by Fall 2022. Recipient must show great promise and potential in the field of history, as demonstrated by, but not limited to, participation in undergraduate research, study abroad, or participation in organizations such as Phi Alpha Theta. Financial need is a consideration. No application is required for the award. For more information, please contact the history department at historyoffice@uwosh.edu. This award will be paid out in Fall 2022. more...

John And Lois Storlie Scholarship Endowment Fund In Computer Science (Sah)

John Anderson Bailey Culinary Endowed Scholarship
The John Anderson Bailey Culinary Endowed Scholarship Fund has been established to honor the memory of John Anderson Bailey. John received his Associates in Applied Science Degree-Restaurant-Hotel Cookery from Madison Area Technical College in 1979. Following graduation, John worked in kitchens in San Francisco; Chicago; Lyon, St. Tropez and Corchevel, France; Washington D.C.; and Eagle River, Wisconsin. John advanced from Broiler Cook to Chef de Cuisine during his career. Because of John’s desire to learn and his adaptability, he became a very valuable member of every kitchen staff he worked with. One of his supervisors wrote that John excelled in his ability to work with a wide range of foods, create new dishes, and had a fine aesthetical feel for presentation. John completed his undergraduate education at the University of Las Vegas, Nevada earning a Bachelor of Science in Hotel Administration and graduating Summa Cum Laude. After he retired from the professional kitchen, John enjoyed preparing delicious meals for family and friends while continuing to find new locally owned restaurants to support and new wines to experience. more...

John Deere Agricultural Tech Continuing Student Scholarship

John E. Strous And Mary M. Rigney Medical Technology Scholarship
This fund is named for John E. Strous, UW Oshkosh medical technology program director from 1991 to 2017, and Mary M. Rigney, medical technology program director from 1985 to 1991. Applicant must be a full-time medical technology major enrolled at the Oshkosh campus. Applicant must be accepted for clinical training at one of the University’s Affiliated Hospital Schools of Medical Technology. Selection is based on academic achievement, leadership abilities, future plans and potential, and extracurricular activities (excluding athletics). Primary overall consideration is to be given to the applicant with the greatest potential to positively impact the Medical Laboratory Science profession in the future. This award will be paid out in Fall 2022. more...

The John F. Kennedy Scholarship is available to incoming full - time freshmen at St. Norbert College. You must demonstrate leadership potential and have a strong college preparatory background to be eligible for this award. more...

John F. Leonardi Memorial Scholarship
This scholarship was established by the parents of UW Oshkosh Professor Emerita Lois Pence. Applicant must be an undergraduate student enrolled at the Oshkosh campus and must be majoring in special education. Applicant must have been admitted, or have applied for fall admission, to the Teacher Education Program. Applicant must have at least junior standing and must exhibit strong academic performance and some experience in working with individuals with disabilities. Financial need is not a consideration. This award will be paid out in Fall 2022. more...

John R. Johnson Scholarship
The John R. Johnson Research Award recognizes and supports undergraduate Communication students with demonstrated academic merit.
Students who have an up-to-date Panther Scholarship Portal General Application and the College of Letters & Science Scholarships and Awards Application will be considered, typically in spring each year between February and April. No additional or separate application is required; students should thoroughly fill out the Panther Scholarship Portal General Application and the College of Letters & Science Scholarships and Awards Application. Awards given in spring are for the following school year so students graduating that same spring or summer are not eligible. E.G. applications reviewed in Spring 2023 are for Fall 2023; students graduating in May or August 2023 are not eligible. more...

John Verhelst Memorial Scholarship
John Verhelst (1949-2019) was a beloved husband, father, and papa who passed away on June 6, 2019 after battling cancer for 19 months. He was devoted to his family and is dearly missed by his wife, two sons and daughters-in-law, and five grandchildren. His “family” included his students and student athletes, whom he cared for deeply and who carry on his legacy. John was a teacher and coach at Monona Grove High School for thirty years, from 1974-2004. He taught History and Physical Education, as well as coaching Football, Basketball and Track. He also coached basketball at Madison College from 2001-2004. Coach V.‘s emphasis on the importance of education was always evident to his students and student athletes. He cared deeply that every student should have the opportunity to pursue his or her dream, and that the power behind the pursuit, bringing one’s dream to fruition, was education. Coach V. believed that students benefited from involvement in athletics, while keeping their studies primary. Commitment and effort were two qualities that John valued in his students and athletes, encouraging them to work hard and always do their best. A mantra used for his basketball team was MTIXE, “mental toughness, intensity, and extra effort.” This scholarship should be awarded to a student who demonstrates those qualities. Thank you: Suzanne, Jason and Rob Verhelst more...

Johnson-Bakker Harmony Scholarship
The Johnson-Bakker Harmony Scholarship is available to students at Chippewa Valley Technical College. You must be a student with nine credits completed with at least a 2.0 GPA. Preference will be given to minority, limited English proficiency and international students. more...

Jon P. Pierce Memorial Scholarship
Employee-Related awards for employees or children of full-time employees of Oshkosh Truck, Inc. who will be enrolling at the University of Wisconsin-Oshkosh. Applicants must be U.S. citizens. Selection based on academic achievement and financial need. Preference given to Nursing or Engineering majors. Nonrenewable. more...

Jon W. Kuse Memorial Scholarship
Jon Kuse was a volunteer firefighter with the Portage Fire Dept. When he retired after 20 years of service, he held the position of Deputy Chief. He served on the Fire Service Advisory Committee at Madison College during the years when the first burn tower was built at the Truax Campus. He was passionate about providing excellence in fire services in the Portage area and encouraged and supported ongoing professional development of fire fighters. This scholarship is available to continuing Fire Technician or Fire Service Certificate students with a GPA of 2.5 or higher. Student must be in their second year of the program. Portage or Columbia County residents preferred. Donor/Thank You Letter: Judith Kuse
HPS Scholarship more...

Jones Dairy Farm Culinary Scholarship
Donor/Thank you letter: Bryon Coleman more...

Joseph Cordeiro Scholarship For Students Studying String Instruments (Sac)
freshman, sophomore, junior or senior to be enrolled full time but does not have to be a music major or minor
member of University Orchestra
proficient in or studying strings (piano or harp are not included in the string category)
good academic standing
entering freshman must submit letter of recommendation from high school orchestra director. Formal application and solo audition tape required; must be willing to give live audition if requested
Performance Guidelines
Piano: Two pieces required (at least one memorized): 1) An allegro sonata movement from
Beethoven, Mozart or Haydn OR Prelude and Fugue by J.S. Bach, 2) Any piece composed in the
Romantic or Contemporary Era. Any repertoire substitutions should be addressed PRIOR to the
audition date.
Strings: a 5-10 minute performance of two contrasting styles or movements of Class A-level
solo literature or above. Memorization is optional. Accompaniment is not required, but is
encouraged.*
Winds: a 5-10 minute performance of two contrasting styles or movements of Class A-level
solo literature or above. Memorization is optional. Accompaniment is not required, but is
encouraged.*
Percussion: a 5-10 minute performance of Class A-level solo literature or above on snare drum
OR timpani, AND a keyboard percussion instrument. Memorization is optional.
Accompaniment is not required, but is encouraged.*
Voice: a 5-10 minute performance of contest-quality solo literature. If the length of one piece is
less than five minutes, a second piece of contrasting tempo, style or language is preferred.
Memorization is optional, but suggested. Vocalists must provide their own accompanist.*
All auditionees will be expected to demonstrate sight-reading abilities
A list of local accompanists is available upon request from the Department of Music.
All auditionees must make their own arrangements with their accompanist of choice.
Questions may be referred to: Dr. Christopher Frye, Department of Music Scholarship
Committee, phone: (608) 785 – 6729 or e-mail: frye.chri@uwlax.edu more...

Journal Foundation Walter Jay And Clara Charlotte Damm Scholarship
Applicant must intend to pursue a career in radio, television, journalism, or a related field. Applicant must be a full-time undergraduate or graduate student enrolled at the Oshkosh campus. Preference will be given to students with a current relationship (e.g. relative of active full- or part-time employees or retiree) with Milwaukee Journal Sentinel, the Milwaukee operations of E.W. Scripps Co. (WTMJ-TV, WTMJ-AM, WKTI-FM), or Gannett Wisconsin (Appleton Post-Crescent, Fond du Lac Reporter, Green Bay Press-Gazette, Manitowoc Herald Times Reporter, Marshfield News Herald, Oshkosh Northwestern, Sheboygan Press, Stevens Point Journal, Wausau Record-Herald, Wisconsin Rapids Daily Tribune). Applicant must have financial need based on the FAFSA. This scholarship is intended for U.S citizens. Applicant should show scholastic ability based on high school or college transcripts as a measure of academic performance and ability to succeed. Previous recipients are eligible to apply. This award will be paid out in Fall 2021. more...

To benefit female Information Technology (“IT”) students enrolled in an IT Associate Degree program. General Category more...

Julie Rortvedt Memorial Scholarship
The Julie Rortvedt Memorial scholarship is available for Pre-hire recruits enrolled at the Madison College Police Academy. Candidates must successfully complete the Police Academy to be considered for the scholarship. The name of the recipient(s) awarded the $500 scholarship will be announced during the Academy graduation. Julie Rortvedt was a retired Detective with the Madison Police Department. She began her career in 1985, as a police officer with the Sun Prairie Police Dept. In 1990, Julie was hired by the Madison Police Department. While at Madison she worked in general assignment, sensitive crimes, on the drug and narcotic task force. She took great pride in teaching about the heroin epidemic and would present to many different groups of people including high school students. She retired as a detective in January 2016 after 30 years in law enforcement. Julie was hired as an instructor with Madison College in 2007.
In 2017, Julie unfortunately was diagnosed with cervical cancer. After 6 months of chemo therapy treatments, she was told the cancer was in remission. Julie continued to teach at the Academy, during her chemotherapy treatments and always had a positive attitude. She viewed this as a opportunity to further teach about the importance of taking care of your body, mind and soul to new police recruits.
Julie inspired many people. She had an extra passion for pre-hire students attending the academy. She wanted the students to succeed and become the best police officer possible.
In June 2019, Julie found out her cancer had returned. After a courageous fight, Julie passed away in August 2019. Julie’s two children chose to honor their mother and continue her legacy by creating a scholarship in her name at the Madison College Police Academy.
The application can be found at the following link each semester when it is open: https://www.supportmadisoncollege.org/special-scholarship-applications/ more...

Karl Iwen Memorial Nursing Scholarship
This scholarship was established in memory of nursing alumnus Karl Iwen ’95. Applicant must be enrolled at the Oshkosh campus and must have been admitted to the traditional or BSN@Home nursing program. Applicant must have graduated from a high school in Marathon County, WI. Preference will be given to graduates of Wausau West High School. Financial need based on an essay will be of secondary consideration only. This award will be paid out in Fall 2022. more...

Karl Maier Scholarship
This academic merit scholarship is given to a declared major in one of the subject areas listed below. Grades and engagement in activities to prepare for a career after college will be considered. Preference will be given to nontraditional students who did not enroll in college directly out of high school and/or students who are the primary financial support and caretaker of a member of their household, for example as a single parent.
Eligible majors include:
Mathematical Sciences
Actuarial Science
Applied Math & Computer Science
Biological Sciences
Microbiology
Chemistry
Biochemistry
Physics
Geosciences
Engineering (all types)
Computer Science
Data Science
Applications are typically in spring each year between February and April. Awards given in spring are for the following school year so students graduating that same spring or summer are not eligible. E.G. applications reviewed in Spring 2023 are for Fall 2023; students graduating in May or August 2023 are not eligible. more...

Katherine Killian Chicquette Scholarship
This scholarship was established in memory of Kay Killian Chicquette, a former teacher in the Appleton Area School District. Applicant must be a full-time undergraduate enrolled at the Oshkosh campus. Applicant must have met Gateway I requirements and been admitted, or have applied for fall admission, to the Teacher Education Program. Applicant must be in good standing within the special and early childhood education program. Preference will be given to applicants with a major in early childhood education. Applicant must demonstrate academic achievement. Financial need based on an essay may be considered, but will not be the deciding factor. This award will be paid out in Fall 2021. more...

Kathryn S. Cappelen Teaching Scholarship (Soe)
freshman, sophomore, junior or senior to be enrolled full time with preference given to entering freshman who are graduates of La Crosse area public schools within the School District of La Crosse
major in either elementary or secondary education leading toward a career in teaching
above average grade point average
financial need should be considered but shall not be determinative of eligibility
most important factors in selecting recipient shall be student’s enthusiasm for teaching career, demonstrated leadership qualities, and high humanistic traits. For this purpose humanistic traits shall include friendliness, warmth, consideration of others, and good “people skills”—traits that promote a happy and nurturing classroom for students of the candidate more...

Kathy G - Madison Auxiliary 623 Nursing Scholarship
Provide the fund details below. The description should include why the fund was created, a history of the fund or how the fund should be used, (e.g., scholarships, equipment purchases, assisting students attending professional conferences, etc.)
The “The Order of Good Things” was founded in February 1898 by six theatre owners. As membership grew, the Bald Eagle was selected as the official emblem and the name changed to “The Fraternal Order of Eagles”. The women’s Auxiliary traces its roots to 1927. The Fraternal Order of Eagles includes nearly 800,000 members and more than 1,500 locations across the United States and Canada. Our motto is “People helping People”.
The F.O.E. donates more than $10 million a year to local communities, fundraisers, charities and more. As part of its philosophy, the F.O.E. gives back 100 percent of monies raised in the form of grants. Fundraisers are conducted at the national, state and local levels for eight major charities; kidney, heart, diabetes, cancer and spinal cord injury funds, a children’s fund, Memorial Foundation, and Alzheimer’s.
The Eagles were instrumental in helping to:
• establish Mother’s Day as a national observance.
• create the $25 million Fraternal Order of Eagles Diabetes Research Center (DRC) at the University of Iowa.
• serve as a driving force behind Social Security.
• end age-based job discrimination with the Jobs After 40 program.
Katherine Susan Gonzagowski
(fondly known as Kathy G.)
Kathy made her debut in this world on July 29, 1941. Little did we know she was destined for fame as a dedicated and active member of the Fraternal Order of Eagles.
Kathy began her Eagle journey by joining the Madison Eagles Auxiliary #623 in 1963 to honor her mother and father, who were a long-term Aerie and Auxiliary members. Kathy went on to serve two terms as the Madison Auxiliary President and in 1978 took over the office of Auxiliary Secretary, a position she held for 17 years. Kathy was instrumental in running the Bingo for our Madison Auxiliary and served many years as the Bingo Chairman. Kathy was also involved in the Madison Drill and Ritual Teams.
As Kathy became involved in the Wisconsin State Auxiliary, she spent many years as the State Membership Chairman and served on many committees. In 1982 she was elected as the State President. Under her leadership, Wisconsin gained 820 new members and three new Auxiliaries.
Kathy was elected as a International Grand Auxiliary Officer and in 1989 she was installed as the Grand Madam President, highest office that can be attained at the International level. For this position, she needed to take a leave of absence from her job for a year as she would spend the time traveling the United States and Canada visiting her Eagle Brothers and Sisters.
She was employed as an LPN at the Central Wisconsin Center for the Developmentally Disabled, where she worked for over 40 years. During her employment, she was active in the Wisconsin State Employee Union, on the Mayor’s committee for Juvenile Delinquency in Madison, and served on the National Advisory Board for Health Care Workers. She also participated in many other local and state programs aimed at improving the lives of others.
Kathy truly believed in the Eagle Motto “People Helping People” and used her nursing experience to spend six weeks to care for a friend who had received a bone marrow transplant. This is so typical of what Kathy did for her Eagle family, her own family, and friends.
Kathy was an avid sports fan. She supported the University of Wisconsin Badgers, the Milwaukee Brewers, and the Green Bay Packers. She was a charter member of the Madison Packer Backers. more...

Laubengayer Family Memorial Endowed Scholarship
Gene Laubengayer retired after a 25 year career in Fire/EMS serving the cities of Madison, Monona, and Milwaukee. Gene also served 7 years as a part-time police officer for Monona, WI. He established this endowed scholarship in appreciation of the high quality protective services opportunities offered by Madison College and to make those opportunities available to future students. Gene completed the Emergency Medical Services Specialist Program. His daughter, Andrea, earned the Fire Protection Technician Associate Dregee. Gene has been a disaster relief leader for the Red Cross, serving Ground Zero in New York following 9/11 and Lake Charles, LA following Hurricane Katrina. These were among nearly 20 national disasters to which he was deployed. This scholarship is available to Emergency Medical Services students.
Donor/Thank You Letter: Andrea Henshue
HPS Scholarship more...

Applicant must be enrolled in the traditional BSN program at the Oshkosh campus. Applicant must be a female, non-traditional (age 25 or older) student with sophomore or junior standing. Applicant must be a U.S. citizen or a legal immigrant with a green card. Applicant must have filed the FAFSA and must not be the recipient of any other scholarship or any form of grant. Applicant may qualify or be the recipient of privately obtained or federal or state loans, subsidized or non-subsidized. This award will be split evenly between the Fall 2021 and Spring 2022 semesters. If the recipient is not enrolled in the spring semester, the second installment will be forfeited. more...

Li Hu Art Student Scholarship
This scholarship was established in honor of retired UW Oshkosh art professor Li Hu. Applicant must be enrolled full- or part-time in a BFA program at the Oshkosh campus. Preference will be given to students with an emphasis in 2D studio art, but others are encouraged to apply. Applicant must have at least junior standing and must have completed at least one 300 level drawing/painting class at time of application. Applicant must have a minimum 2.75 cumulative GPA in their major. Academic achievement shall not be a selection consideration beyond meeting the minimum GPA requirement. Selection will be based upon promise and potential to succeed in drawing/painting. Students intending to pursue an MFA will be given first preference. This award will be paid out in Fall 2022. more...

Lina Vergara Memorial Scholarship
This scholarship was established in memory of Lina Vergara, a student in the College of Education and Human Services. Applicant must be a full-time elementary education major enrolled at the Oshkosh campus. Applicant must have been admitted, or have applied for fall admission, to the Teacher Education Program. Applicant must be in good academic standing and must have a minimum 3.0 cumulative GPA. Applicant must demonstrate involvement in extracurricular (excluding athletics) or volunteer activities as a high school or college student. Preference will be given to students working as Community Advisors and/or volunteering in programs involving kids, such as Big Brothers Big Sisters or Best Buddies. Preference will be given to applicants who are known for going above and beyond in welcoming new or shy students and making them feel comfortable in the high school or college environment. Attendance at the University’s Scholarship Reception in May 2022 is required (provided the event is held), provided the donor is able to attend. This award will be split evenly between the Fall 2022 and Spring 2023 semesters. If the recipient is not enrolled in the spring semester, the second installment will be forfeited. more...

This scholarship was established by Linda L. Bartelt ’94 MBA and Jeffrey D. Bartelt of Oshkosh. Applicant must be a full-time undergraduate student enrolled at the Oshkosh campus. Applicant must be admitted, or have applied for spring admission, to the College of Business. Applicant must have at least junior standing and must have a minimum 2.5 cumulative GPA. Applicant must show an interest in entrepreneurship, small business, and/or family business. Applicant must also show evidence of entrepreneurial activities (declared emphasis, extracurricular activities (excluding athletics), employment at a small business). This award will be paid out in Fall 2022. more...

Lindy Shannon Music Scholarship (Sac)
freshman, sophomore, junior or senior to be enrolled full time with a major in music
above average grade point average
financial need should be considered
special application from the Music Department
Performance Guidelines
Piano: Two pieces required (at least one memorized): 1) An allegro sonata movement from
Beethoven, Mozart or Haydn OR Prelude and Fugue by J.S. Bach, 2) Any piece composed in the
Romantic or Contemporary Era. Any repertoire substitutions should be addressed PRIOR to the
audition date.
Strings: a 5-10 minute performance of two contrasting styles or movements of Class A-level
solo literature or above. Memorization is optional. Accompaniment is not required, but is
encouraged.*
Winds: a 5-10 minute performance of two contrasting styles or movements of Class A-level
solo literature or above. Memorization is optional. Accompaniment is not required, but is
encouraged.*
Percussion: a 5-10 minute performance of Class A-level solo literature or above on snare drum
OR timpani, AND a keyboard percussion instrument. Memorization is optional.
Accompaniment is not required, but is encouraged.*
Voice: a 5-10 minute performance of contest-quality solo literature. If the length of one piece is
less than five minutes, a second piece of contrasting tempo, style or language is preferred.
Memorization is optional, but suggested. Vocalists must provide their own accompanist.*
All auditionees will be expected to demonstrate sight-reading abilities
A list of local accompanists is available upon request from the Department of Music.
All auditionees must make their own arrangements with their accompanist of choice.
Questions may be referred to: Dr. Christopher Frye, Department of Music Scholarship
Committee, phone: (608) 785 – 6729 or e-mail: frye.chri@uwlax.edu more...

Lloyd Larson Memorial Scholarship
The Lloyd Larson Memorial Scholarship was established to commemorate a generous and creative English and Communications instructor. He was dedicated to the success of his students. Lloyd’s career spanned just over 30 years. He joined the college on September 28, 1972 and worked until his death August 8, 2002. His primary focus was teaching English Composition I, Creative Writing and Fundamentals of Speech. Applicants must be full-time, continuing Veterinary Tech students with a 3.0 GPA or higher. Donor/Thank You Letter: Marilyn Larson more...

Lou Mcglothian Memorial Scholarship
The Lou McGlothian Memorial Scholarship (LMMS) has been made possible by The Business Council,
Inc. and its member corporations. This scholarship is awarded each year to at least one (1) college
junior, senior OR graduate student provided they meet the scholarship criteria. This scholarship was
created in 2009 in honor of LouVenice (Lou) McGlothian for her 14 years of service with The Business
Council (TBC). Lou served as TBC’s administrative professional and assisted with the efforts and
objectives of TBC. Lou also opened her home to numerous foster children during her lifetime. The
student(s) selected for the 2014-15 LMMS will receive $2,500 a year ($1,250 each semester).
The recipient will be chosen by members of the Scholarship Committee. The decision of the
Scholarship Committee will be final.
Students must meet the following criteria:
1. Student must be a U.S. citizen (or an eligible noncitizen, as defined in the Free Application for
Federal Student Aid (FAFSA);
2. Student attends a 4-year college, or will transfer to a four-year college after successfully
completing an associate’s degree by Spring 2015 (proof of admission to a four-year
college/university must be submitted with the application);
3. Student is a college junior, senior or a graduate student, as defined by the number of cumulative
credits, as of the Fall 2014 semester;
4. Student is of African-American, Asian-American, Hispanic or Native-American ancestry;
5. Student has declared a major. Student must attach proof of their declared major (i.e., a form
filled out by the student and/or an advisor declaring a major);
6. Student must have a 3.00 or higher grade point average and must maintain a 3.00 or higher grade
point average while receiving the scholarship;
7. Student must submit a recent copy of his/her official college transcript;
8. Student must complete a 2014-15 Lou McGlothian Memorial Scholarship application;
9. Student has applied for federal financial aid and can attach a copy of his/her 2013-2014 Student
Aid Report (SAR) to the scholarship application. If it is not submitted at the time of the
application, it must be forwarded before the interviewing process begins on December 3, 2014;
10. Student must attach a copy of his/her Financial Aid Offer/Award Letter from the college they
attend. If it is not submitted at the time of the application, it must be forwarded before the
interviewing process begins on December 3, 2014.
11. Student must submit a self-written, typed essay, not exceeding 2 pages, answering the following:
1) Why he/she feels deserving of this scholarship?
2) Once you finish your education, how do you plan to impact your community?
The student must attach this to the scholarship application;
12. Student has two written recommendations from 1) a professor in their declared major field; and
2) an academic advisor or another professor;
13. If selected for a panel interview, the student must be available on Wednesday, December 3,
2014, for this purpose.
15. If selected as the winner of the Lou McGlothian Memorial Scholarship, the student (or a
designee) must attend the Annual Strategic Partnership Luncheon on Thursday, February 19,
2015.
Completed applications should be mailed to The Business Council’s Scholarship Manager, Cassandra
Flagg at 756 N. Milwaukee Street, Suite 400, Milwaukee, WI 53202, postmarked on or before Friday,
October 31, 2014. Students are asked to paperclip each piece of information together in the order
ranked above (#7-12 and the application should appear on top.)
Students whose applications have been received and reviewed will be notified by Thursday, January
22, 2015 of their application status.
The Business Council’s was established in 1998 and its mission is to create and maximize access for
economic opportunities and resources for our members, which will support the financial stability of
ethnically diverse-owned businesses and stimulate their expansion.
If you have questions regarding the Lou McGlothian Memorial Scholarship, or the scholarship process,
contact Cassandra Flagg at The Business Council, Inc. at cflagg@mmac.org via telephone at
414.287.4108.
Application is available in Financial Aid Office 215 Graff Main Hall more...

Lucile Morton Grams Scholarship
Applicant must be a full-time undergraduate enrolled at the Oshkosh campus. Applicant must have no more than 89 credits completed and must have a strong desire to continue their education. Academic achievement is a consideration only in that the applicant must have achieved a minimum 2.5 GPA. Applicant must have financial need based on the FAFSA and must not qualify for federal grants (loans are acceptable). Applicant must demonstrate the need for financial support due to special circumstances. This award will be split evenly between the Fall 2022 and Spring 2023 semesters. If the recipient is not enrolled in the spring semester, the second installment will be forfeited. more...

The cost of education continues to increase. Tuition and other educational costs are being met primarily through loans. Nearly all Madison College alumni reside in Wisconsin after graduation. Lower loan debt will enable them to meet the high cost of living in and around Dane County. This scholarship is for New Students to Madison College. Thank you letter: Laura Lussier-Lee more...

M.C. Davey Scholarship Fund
This scholarship is being established to support women of color who are enrolled full or part time. The donor was motivated by concerns about the disparity of resources for education in our community. The funds can be used for scholarship and/or educational expenses, such as equipment purchases for items students may need while in school (e.g. a computer and internet access). In recognition of the increasing importance of information technology in education and in career opportunities, it is preferred that recipients be enrolled in the IT program or in the school which that program resides, ASET (Applied Science, Engineering and Technology). more...

M3 Insurance Scholarship
The M3 Insurance Solutions for Business (M3) Scholarship is designed to promote educational opportunities for deserving students in the Insurance Program at Madison Area Technical College. M3 and its employees believe that it is their responsibility to give back to the communities where we work and thrive. M3’s charitable giving program focuses on programs that align with our business practice; health improvement, safety improvement and disaster relief. M3 is independently owned and currently employs 180 insurance professionals. Together, we serve more than 5,000 clients in Wisconsin to provide a comprehensive suite of consultative services in property, casualty and workers’ comp insurance. Student must be enrolled or planning to enroll in an Insurance course(s) and is not receiving employer reimbursement. Donor/Thank You Letter: Michael Victorson more...

Madison College Intercultural Council Excellence In Diversity Award
This award recognizes the outstanding accomplishments of individuals or teams who have contributed to the diversity and inclusion practices at Madison College. it is being funded by contributions from the College, including Intercultural Council members. Awards will be made based on the Intercultural Council committee (ICC) decision. A rigorous nomination/selection process is used to determine recipients. Donor/Thank You Letter: Valentina Ahedo more...

Madison College Rainbow Scholarship
In 2018, the endowed Rainbow Scholarship was made possible by QBE North America, a branch of the Australian insurer QBE, with a generous donation of $20,000 to the Madison College Foundation. In 2019, and 2020 QBE North America added an additional $5,000 each year to the Madison College Rainbow Scholarship fund. This fund will be used to award up to four $1,000 scholarships each semester to high school students planning to attend Madison College and/or currently enrolled Madison College students who identify as part of the LGBT community (e.g., lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, intersex, non-binary, asexual, or ally). Both U.S. and non-U.S. citizens are eligible to apply. Scholarship funds may be used for tuition, fees, books, and course-related supplies needed for Madison College classes.
Rainbow Scholarship awards are for one semester only and are nonrenewable. However, students may reapply for additional scholarships each semester and will be considered with other new applicants.
Eligibility Requirements:
The applicant must self-identify as part of the LGBT community.
For high school graduates new to Madison College, the applicant must have a High School cumulative GPA of at least 2.0 and must be enrolled in 6 or more credits at Madison College for the upcoming semester. Only degree course credits count toward this enrollment requirement. Preference will be given to students enrolled full-time.
For students currently enrolled at Madison College, the applicant must have a Madison College cumulative GPA of at least 2.0 and must be enrolled in 6 or more credits at Madison College for the upcoming semester. Only degree course credits count toward this enrollment requirement. Preference will be given to students enrolled full-time.
The applicant is not receiving other financial support (e.g., full scholarships or full tuition remission) that covers all educational costs (e.g., tuition, fees, and books) for the semester in which the applicant will receive a Rainbow Scholarship.
The applicant must demonstrate evidence of service to the LGBT community.
The application in posted at the link below when open.
https://www.supportmadisoncollege.org/special-scholarship-applications/ more...

Madison College Women’s Leadership Network Scholarship
This fund has been created by the Madison College Women’s Leadership Network in order to provide opportunities to inspire and encourage women to pursue their educational goals including, but not limited to, leadership roles. Donor/Thank you letter: Women’s Leadership Network more...

Madison Elks is a charitable organization that provides scholarships, youth activities and helps support worthwhile community programs. Full or part-time continuing Madison College students may apply. Must have a GPA of 3.0 or higher. Veterans are strongly encouraged to apply. Donor/Thank You Letter: Sherie Sasso, Madison Elks Chapter 410 more...

Madison Gas And Electric Endowed Scholarship
This scholarship is available to full-time students with a GPA of 2.5 or higher. MG&E service area residents preferred.

Madison Kipp Corporation Scholarship
This scholarship is available to Madison East, LaFollette, Memorial, West and Sun Prairie High School seniors enrolling in Madison College technical programs related to manufacturing processes. Examples include machine tool, welding, industrial maintenance, mechanical design, and pre-engineering transfer. If the recipient’s parent is a Madison Kipp employee, the student may enroll in any degree program. Scholarships are paid in two installments of $750 each semester. Students are expected to enroll full-time and maintain a minimum 2.0 grade point average to earn the second installment.
Donor/Thank You Letter: Tony Koblinski more...

Madison Professional Police Officer Scholarship For Criminal Justice Students
This fund was created by the Madison Professional Police Officer Association & Association of Madison Police Supervisors in efforts to increase underrepresented individuals in the law enforcement workforce. In addition, this fund was created to assist Madison College Criminal Justice students whom are interested in a career in law enforcement and are in need of financial assistance. This will also assist the recipients with finding employment by offering an unpaid internship with the Madison Police Department. Once at the Madison Police Department the recipients will also be assigned mentors.
Please Contact Jack Pace at JPace@madisoncollege.edu if you have any questions about this scholarship or how to apply. more...

Marcia Larson Memorial Scholarship
Marcia was a graduate of the Commercial Art program and a shining example of the quality professionals it can nurture. Marcia and her boyfriend were victims of a car crash due to a drunk driver. Her mother, Dolly, started at Madison College that following summer and completed Marcia’s program in 2004. This scholarship is available to full-time students accepted into the Graphic Design or Visual Communications-Media Design programs with a GPA of 3.0 or higher.

Margaret Brown Scholarship Endowment Fund (Sac)
recipient must be enrolled full time at UW-La Crosse with a major or minor in music
recipient must enroll in trumpet lessons
recipient must be in ensemble of either Concert Band, Music Band or Jazz Band
recipient must be in good academic standing with a grade point average of at least 2.75
recipient may be a freshman, sophomore, junior or senior
audition is required for incoming freshman and for renewability of the award
Performance Guidelines
Piano: Two pieces required (at least one memorized): 1) An allegro sonata movement from
Beethoven, Mozart or Haydn OR Prelude and Fugue by J.S. Bach, 2) Any piece composed in the
Romantic or Contemporary Era. Any repertoire substitutions should be addressed PRIOR to the
audition date.
Strings: a 5-10 minute performance of two contrasting styles or movements of Class A-level
solo literature or above. Memorization is optional. Accompaniment is not required, but is
encouraged.*
Winds: a 5-10 minute performance of two contrasting styles or movements of Class A-level
solo literature or above. Memorization is optional. Accompaniment is not required, but is
encouraged.*
Percussion: a 5-10 minute performance of Class A-level solo literature or above on snare drum
OR timpani, AND a keyboard percussion instrument. Memorization is optional.
Accompaniment is not required, but is encouraged.*
Voice: a 5-10 minute performance of contest-quality solo literature. If the length of one piece is
less than five minutes, a second piece of contrasting tempo, style or language is preferred.
Memorization is optional, but suggested. Vocalists must provide their own accompanist.*
All auditionees will be expected to demonstrate sight-reading abilities
A list of local accompanists is available upon request from the Department of Music.
All auditionees must make their own arrangements with their accompanist of choice.
Questions may be referred to: Dr. Christopher Frye, Department of Music Scholarship
Committee, phone: (608) 785 – 6729 or e-mail: frye.chri@uwlax.edu more...

Margaret E. Radzibon Scholarship
Margaret Ellen Radzibon was a talented illustrator who never had the opportunitv to pursue art school. After graduating high school in Dearborn, Michigan at the age of 17 she went to work at a bank to help support her family. Margaret’s older brother was injured in World War II and he had a wife and two small sons to support. Margaret was an excellent student who believed in the power of education to improve lives. This scholarship was set up by Margaret’ s daughter to honor her memory and help other art students achieve their dreams. This scholarship is available to support students who participate in the Alternative Spring Break Program. Donor/Thank You Letter: Kathleen Radionoff more...

This scholarship was established as a memorial to Maria de Refugio (Susana Valtierra’s mother). Maria had an 8th grade education and always emphasized to her children the importance of getting a college education. All eight of her children have graduated from high school and six have graduated from college. This scholarship is available to full or part-time Liberal Arts Transfer students with a GPA of 2.5 or higher. Must have financial need, complete 25 hours of community service and must be first generation minority/under represented group. Donor/Thank You Letter: Susan Valtierra more...

Marian Messerschmidt Scholarship
Marian worked at Madison College from age 18 to 65. She worked in registration and used a manual typewriter. She was hired on October 15, 1925 and retired June 1, 1971. She established this scholarship to support students in the Judicial Reporting Program. more...
